description.p: The pallid half-elf mutters an incantation under his breath, and his shadow comes alive, taking the form of a massive wolf. At his command the wolf pounces on his attacker, a foolish bandit, knocking him to the ground. The half-elf chants another incantation, and as pulsing green orbs of acidic energy forms in his hands as the bandit struggles in vain against the massive shadow-beast. The bandit lets out a piercing scream, filled with regret, as the two spheres of acidic energy fly towards him.

As the grass and trees smolder from the great dragon’s fiery blast, the smoke clears to reveal a young man. His clothes burned away to reveal patches of golden scales. His eyes flash a fierce gold, and white jets of flame burst from his fingertips. The dragon reels from the impact, crashing into the dirt. He had underestimated this mortal, how had he come to wield power rivaling a dragon?

The young halfling girl ducked into an alleyway, quickly hiding the stolen loaf of bread under her cloak. Back in the market she had come from, chaos had broken out. She had attempted a simple enchantment, just enough to convince the baker to give her a loaf of bread for free, but her magic had other plans. As she whispered to the baker, a crack - like a bolt of lightning - could be heard throughout the market, and suddenly all the produce in the square spoiled. She cursed this power that caused her parents to abandon her to the streets. If she could only control this power she could do much to ease the suffering of other urchins like herself.

Sorcerers are rare in the world, and it’s unusual to find a sorcerer who is not involved in the adventuring life in some way. People with magical power seething in their veins soon discover that the power doesn’t like to stay quiet. A sorcerer’s magic wants to be wielded, and it has a tendency to spill out in unpredictable ways if it isn’t called on.

Sorcerers often have obscure or quixotic motivations driving them to adventure. Some seek a greater understanding of the magical force that infuses them, or the answer to the mystery of its origin. Others hope to find a way to get rid of it, or to unleash its full potential. Whatever their goals, sorcerers are every bit as useful to an adventuring party as wizards, making up for a comparative lack of breadth in their magical knowledge with enormous flexibility in using the spells they know.

Magic is a part of every sorcerer, suffusing body, mind, and spirit with a latent power that waits to be tapped. Some sorcerers wield magic that springs from an ancient bloodline infused with the magic of powerful beings or elemental energies. Others carry a raw uncontrolled magic within them, chaotic storms that manifest in unexpected ways.

The appearance of sorcerous powers is wildly unpredictable. Some arcane bloodlines produce exactly one sorcerer in every generation, but in other lines of descent every individual is a sorcerer. Most of the time, the talents of sorcery appear as apparent flukes. Some sorcerers can’t name the origin of their power, while others trace it to strange events in their own lives. The touch of a celestial, the blessing of a djinni at birth, or the taste of water from a mysterious spring might spark the gift of sorcery. So too might the gift of a deity of magic, exposure to the elemental forces of the Inner Planes or the maddening chaos of Limbo, or a glimpse into the inner workings of reality.

Sorcerers have no use for the spellbooks and ancient tomes of magic lore that wizards rely on, nor do they rely on a patron to grant their spells as warlocks do. By learning to harness and channel their own inborn magic, they can discover new and staggering ways to unleash their power.

The most important question to consider when creating your sorcerer is the origin of your power. As a starting character, you’ll choose a sorcerous origin from the options detailed in the class description, but the exact source of your power is up to you to decide. Is it a family curse, passed down to you from distant ancestors? Or did some extraordinary event leave you blessed with inherent magic but perhaps scarred as well?

You can make a sorcerer quickly by following these suggestions. First, make Charisma your highest ability score followed by Constitution. Second, choose the hermit background. Third, choose the light, prestidigitation, ray of frost, and shocking grasp cantrips, along with the 1st-level spells shield and magic missile.
If your group uses the optional rule on multiclassing in the Player’s Handbook, here’s what you need to know if you choose the sorcerer as one of your classes.
Ability Score Minimum. As a multiclass character, you must have at least a 13 in Charisma to take a level in this class, or to take a level in another class if you are a sorcerer.

Spellcasting. If you have the Spellcasting class feature from another class, you can use the sorcery points you gain as a sorcerer to cast spells you know, or have prepared, from classes with the Spellcasting class feature, and you can use the spell slots you gain from the Spellcasting class feature to cast sorcerer spells.
As an lowercaseclassname, you gain the following class features.

ul.li: Hit Dice: 1d6 per lowercaseclassname level
Hit Points at 1st Level: 6 + your Constitution modifier
Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d6 (or 4) + your Constitution modifier per lowercaseclassname level after 1st
Armor: None
Weapons: Daggers, darts, slings, quarterstaffs, and light crossbows
Tools: None
Saving Throws: Constitution, Charisma
Skills: Choose two from Arcana, Deception, Insight, Intimidation, Persuasion, and Religion

description.p: You start with the following equipment, in addition to the equipment granted by your background:

ul.li: (a) a light crossbow and 20 bolts or (b) any simple weapon
(a) a dungeoneer’s pack or (b) an explorer’s pack
Two daggers

setters.set: Become the font of magic you always wanted to be.
As a multiclass character, you must have at least a 13 in Charisma to take a level in this class, or to take a level in another class if you are a sorcerer.

description.p: You have been infused with a spark arcane magic. Starting at 1st level, this innate spark fuels your spells. See chapter 10 of the Player’s Handbook for the general rules of Spellcasting, and chapter 11 for the sorcerer spell list.
At 1st level, you know four cantrips of your choice from the sorcerer spell list. You learn an additional sorcerer cantrip of your choice at 4th level and another at 10th level.

The Sorcerer table shows how many sorcery points you have to cast your Spells of 1st-level and higher. To cast one of these sorcerer spells, you must expend the amount of sorcery points indicated in the table below. You regain all expended sorcery points when you finish a long rest.
For example, as a 3rd level sorcerer, you can cast the spell burning hands at 2nd-level by spending 3 sorcery points.

Your sorcerer level limits the potency of spells that you can cast. This is reflected in the Spell Limit column of the Sorcerer Table. For example, as a 5th-level sorcerer, you are limited to casting spells of 3rd-level or lower.

You know two 1st-level spells of your choice from the sorcerer spell list. The Spells Known column of the Sorcerer Table shows when you learn more sorcerer spells of your choice. Each of these spells must be of a level equal to your Spell Limit or lower. For instance, when you reach 3rd level in this class, you can learn one new spell of 1st or 2nd-level.

Additionally, when you gain a level in this class, you can choose one of the sorcerer spells you know and replace it with another spell from the sorcerer spell list, which also must be of a level equal to your Spell Limit or lower.

Charisma is your spellcasting ability for your sorcerer spells, so you use your Charisma whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Charisma modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a sorcerer spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.
Spell save DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Charisma modifier
Spell attack modifier = your proficiency bonus + your Charisma modifier

Your body itself is your spellcasting focus, you do not need a spellcasting focus to cast spells. However, you must have one free hand in order to cast spells that require somatic or material components. If a spell has a material component with a gold cost, you must still supply it to cast the spell.
When you finish a long rest, you can choose one sorcerer spell you know and replace it with another sorcerer spell of a level equal to, or lower then, your Spell Limit.

sheet.description: You have {{sorcery-points}} Sorcery Points. You can cast spells by expending sorcery points. (1st > 2 pts, 2nd > 3 pts, 3rd > 5pts, 4th > 6 pts, 5th > 7 pts). Your body is your spellcasting focus. You must have one free hand to cast spells.

description.p: Your spellcasting ability is Charisma.
Your spellcasting ability is Intelligence.
Your spellcasting ability is Wisdom.

At 1st level, you choose the source of your arcane power from the following options: Emberheart, Stoneblood, Stormsoul, Waveborn, and Alternate rules for Draconic Bloodline, Wild Magic, Divine Soul, Shadow Magic, and Aberrant Mind.
Your choice grants you features when you choose it at 1st level and again at 6th, 14th, and 18th level.

Each sorcerous origin has a list of origin spells that you gain at the sorcerer levels noted in the origin description. These spells count as sorcerer spells for you, but they don’t count against your number of Spells Known. These spells are also considered part of the sorcerer spell list for you.

Starting at 2nd level, your innate spark of magic allows you to produce wondrous magical effects. You learn two manifestations of your choice from the list at the end of this class description. You gain additional manifestations of your choice at higher levels, as shown in the Manifestations Known column of the Sorcerer table.
When you cast a spell, you can only apply one of your manifestation abilities to it, unless otherwise noted.
When you gain a level in this class, you can choose one of the manifestations you know and replace it with another of your choice that you meet the prerequisites for.

sheet.description: You can use only one Arcane Manifestation on a spell when you cast it, unless otherwise noted. At the end of a Long Rest, you can choose to replace one of your Metamagic options with another of your choice.

description.p: You have learned to regenerate your innate arcane potential while resting. Starting at 3rd level, when you finish a short rest you can choose to regain expended sorcery points equal to your sorcerer level.
Once you use this ability you must finish a long rest before you can use it again.

sheet.description: At the end of a short rest you can recover {{level:sorcerer}} sorcery points.

description.p: When you reach 4th Level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two Ability Scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Starting at 10th level, you can reach deep within yourself to spontaneously cast spells currently unknown to you. As an action, choose a spell from the sorcerer spell list that you do not know, that is of a level you can cast, expend the appropriate amount of sorcery points, and cast the spell as if it was one of your Spells Known.
Once you use this ability you must complete a long rest before you can use it again.

sheet.description: Choose a spell from the sorcerer spell list that you do not know, that is of a level you can cast, expend the appropriate amount of sorcery points, and cast the spell as if it was one of your Spells Known.

description.p: As you grow in arcane power and might you have learned to produce overwhelming feats of magic. At 11th level, your innate sorcerous power manifests as a Sorcerous Arcanum, a powerful arcane spell. Choose one 6th-level spell from the sorcerer spell list as this arcanum. It does not count against your number of Spells Known.
You can cast this spell once, at 6th-level, without expending any sorcery points, and you regain all uses of your Sorcerous Arcanum when you finish a long rest.

Your Sorcerous Arcanum spells do not count against your total number of Spells Known. If you select a sorcerer spell of 5th-level or lower that you wish to upcast as your Sorcerous Arcanum spell, it must also be one of your Spells Known if you wish to cast it with your sorcery feature.

When you cast your Sorcerous Arcanum spells you can apply a manifestation ability that you know to the spell as long as the spell is eligible. At the end of a long rest, you can choose to replace one of your Sorcerous Arcanum spells with an eligible spell from the sorcerer spell list.

sheet.description: You can cast each of your Sorcerous Arcanum spells once without expending sorcery points. When you cast your Sorcerous Arcanum spells you can apply a Metamagic you know to the spell as long as the spell is eligible. At the end of a long rest you can replace one of your Sorcerous Arcanum spells with a spell of the same level from the sorcerer spell list.

description.p: You have complete mastery over the arcane power that resides within you, and you now have nearly limitless potential. Arcane magic itself bends to your whims, and you can fundamentally alter spells and other magical effects at will. Upon reaching 20th level in this class, the sorcery point costs of your manifestation abilities all have their sorcery point costs reduced by 1 (to a minimum of 1).

In addition, you can apply an unlimited number of your manifestation abilities to your spells, provided you have the required sorcery points to do so, and the spell meets the requirements for the manifestations you wish to apply.

sheet.description: You can apply any number of manifestations to a spell, as long as you have the sorcery points to do so, and the spell meets the requirements for the manifestation. Your manifestations all have their sorcery point cost reduced by 1 (to a minimum of 1).

description.p: As an emberheart sorcerer, you have been touched by primordial fire. Did you receive this power in a deal with a noble Efreeti, as a gift from an ancient dragon, or were you born near a rift leading to the elemental plane of fire? This ember of primal flame within you may manifest in your outward appearance or through your emotions.

Most emberheart sorcerers revel in their exotic appearance; flame red hair, eyes like glowing embers, or dark skin with magma peering through cracks. How does your flaming soul affect your decisions? Are you a raging inferno, unable to be controlled? Or, do you resist the urges of your bloodline, seeking to master your power?

Whenever you gain a sorcerer level, you can replace one spell you gained from this feature with another spell of the same level. The new spell must be a conjuration or evocation spell from the druid, sorcerer, or wizard spell list.
Emberheart Spells

sheet.description: Whenever you gain a sorcerer level, you can replace one spell you gained from this feature with another spell of the same level.

description.p: The primordial fire in your soul emboldens you. Starting at 1st level, you are resistant to fire damage and have advantage on saving throws to resist being charmed or frightened.

In addition, your connection to elemental fire allows you to speak, read, and write Ignan. This allows you to communicate with creatures that speak Primordial and its other dialects: Aquan, Auran, and Terran.

sheet.description: You have advantage on saving throws to resist being charmed or frightened. You can speak Primordial and its other dialects.

description.p: Starting at 6th level, when you strike down a creature with flame, you can cause fire to erupt forth from their ruin. As a reaction, when you reduce a small or larger creature to 0 hit points with a spell that deals fire damage, you force creatures of your choice within 10 feet of the slain creature to make Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, creatures take fire damage based on the size of the slain creature, as indicated in the table below. On a successful save, creatures take half as much fire damage.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

sheet.description: When you reduce a creature to 0 hit points with a spell that deals fire damage, creatures within 10 feet must make a Dexterity saving throw or take fire damage based on the size of the creature, or half damage on a successful save..

description.p: You are restored by flame. Beginning at 14th level, when you cast a spell of 1st-level or higher that deals fire damage, you can choose to immediately gain temporary hit points equal to the level at which the spell was cast + your Charisma modifier (minimum of 1).

sheet.description: When you cast a spell of 1st-level or higher that deals fire damage, you can choose to gain temporary hit points equal to the level at which the spell was cast + {{cha-mod:min-one}}.

description.p: You have mastered the elemental fire that burns within your soul, allowing you to become more elemental then mortal. Upon reaching 18th level, you no longer need to eat, drink, or sleep, and you are immune to fire damage.

In addition, when you take damage from a creature within 60 feet, that you can see, you can use your reaction to rebuke them with elemental flame. The creature must make a Dexterity saving throw, and on a failed save they take fire damage equal to your sorcerer level.

sheet.description: When you take damage from a creature within 60 feet, that you can see, you can use your reaction to rebuke them with elemental flame. The creature must make a Dexterity saving throw, and on a failed save they take {{level:sorcerer}} fire damage. In addition, you no longer need to eat, drink, or sleep, and you are immune to fire damage.

description.p: You are a stoneblood sorcerer, a mortal with an intrinsic tie to the elemental plane of earth. The stalwart power of stone suffuses your body making you immovable and unyielding as the mountains. Did you gain this power from an ancient earth elemental, barter for it with the greedy Dao, or are you descended from the original dwarves, molded from the bedrock of the world? The power that dwells within your blood urges you to remain steadfast in your decisions, and hoard the fruits of the earth; precious gems and alloys.
How does your earthen affinity outwardly manifest itself? Are you constantly covered in a thin coating of dust and sand, or are your features austere as if you were cut from marble?

Whenever you gain a sorcerer level, you can replace one spell you gained from this feature with another spell of the same level. The new spell must be a conjuration or evocation spell from the druid, sorcerer, or wizard spell list.
Stoneblood Spells

td.em: steel wind strike, wall of stone

sheet.description: Whenever you gain a sorcerer level, you can replace one spell you gained from this feature with another spell of the same level.

description.p: You can draw upon the earthen magic within you to harden your physical form for a limited time. Starting at 1st level, you can use a bonus action to take on an elemental form, your physical form becomes covered in rock and stone, and you gain the following benefits:

ul.li: You gain temporary hit points equal to your sorcerer level.
If you are not wearing armor or wielding a shield, your armor class is equal to 13 + your Constitution modifier.
You use your Constitution modifier for the attack and damage rolls of your unarmed strikes.
Your unarmed strikes deal 1d10 bludgeoning damage. If you strike with two free hands, the d10 becomes a d12.

description.p: This transformation lasts for one minute, or until you end it as a bonus action or fall unconscious. You can use this ability a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

In addition, your connection to elemental earth allows you to speak, read, and write Terran. This allows you to communicate with creatures that speak Primordial and it’s other dialects: Aquan, Auran, and Ignan.

sheet.description: You become covered in rock and stone for up to 1 minute. You gain {{level:sorcerer}} temporary hit points. If you are not wearing armor or wielding a shield, your AC is {{heart-of-stone:ac}}. You use your Constitution modifier for the attack and damage rolls of your unarmed strikes. Your unarmed strikes deal 1d10 bludgeoning damage. If you strike with two free hands, the d10 becomes a d12. You can speak Primordial and its other dialects.

You become covered in rock and stone for up to 1 minute. You gain {{level:sorcerer}} temporary hit points. If you are not wearing armor or wielding a shield, your AC is {{heart-of-stone:ac}}. You use your Constitution modifier for the attack and damage rolls of your unarmed strikes. Your unarmed strikes deal 1d10 bludgeoning damage and count as magical for the sake of overcoming resistances and immunities.. If you strike with two free hands, the d10 becomes a d12. You can speak Primordial and its other dialects.

description.p: You can empower your strikes with the power of pure rock. Starting at 6th level, when you hit with an unarmed strike or melee weapon attack, you can expend sorcery points to deal additional magical bludgeoning damage to the target.
This damage is 2d6 for 2 sorcery points, plus 1d6 for each additional sorcery point you expend, to a maximum of 6d6.
In addition, while in your Heart of Earth elemental form, damage from your unarmed strikes counts as magical for the sake of overcoming resistances and immunities.

sheet.description: When you hit a creature with a melee weapon attack or unarmed strike, you can expend sorcery points to deal additional bludgeoning damage to the target. The damage is 2d6 for 2 sorcery points, plus 1d6 for each additional sorcery point you expend, up to a maximum of 6d6.

description.p: Starting at 6th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action. Moreover, you can cast one of your sorcerer cantrips in place of one of those attacks.

sheet.description: You can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action. Moreover, you can cast one of your sorcerer cantrips in place of one of those attacks.

description.p: Your connection to the elemental magic of earth allows you to extend its mystical protection to you and your allies. Beginning at 14th level, you can use a bonus action to expend 3 sorcery points and grant an aegis of protective earth magic to one creature you touch, including possibly yourself. The creature gains resistance to nonmagical bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage for 1 minute.

When a creature hits the protected target with a melee attack, you can use your reaction to teleport to an unoccupied space within 5 feet of the attacker and make one melee weapon attack against them. You can teleport in this way only if you and the attacker are on the same surface.
If you use this ability to grant a protective aegis to another creature, the effect immediately ends for the first creature.

sheet.description: You expend 3 sorcery points and touch a creature. The creature gains resistance to nonmagical bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage for 1 minute. When a creature hits the protected target with a melee attack, you can use your reaction to teleport to an unoccupied space within 5 feet of the attacker and make one melee weapon attack against them.

description.p: You have mastered the elemental earth that dwells deep within your soul, allowing you to become more elemental then mortal. Upon reaching 18th level, you no longer need to eat, drink, or sleep, and you are permanently resistant to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage.
In addition, you can have your Aegis of Stone active on up to three creatures at one time.

sheet.description: You no longer need to eat, drink, or sleep. You can have your Aegis of Stone active on up to three creatures at one time.

description.p: Within you dwells a mote of pure elemental air, marking you as a stormsoul sorcerer. From this mote you draw an innate affinity with the raging storms and gentle breezes of the material world. How did you come to bear this blustery power within you? Were you blessed at birth by a noble Djinni, a prince of elemental wind, did your parents make a deal with a primordial air elemental, or, by chance or by designe, were you born in the eye of a raging storm?

Whatever the origin of your power, the primal storm within you drives you from whimsical and calm, to wild and violent with little warning. Do you resist the call of your nomadic soul, or do you give in to your wild whims?

Whenever you gain a sorcerer level, you can replace one spell you gained from this feature with another spell of the same level. The new spell must be a conjuration or evocation spell from the druid, sorcerer, or wizard spell list.
Stormsoul Spells

sheet.description: Whenever you gain a sorcerer level, you can replace one spell you gained from this feature with another spell of the same level.

description.p: When you call upon your inner storm you gain the ability to fly, if only briefly. Starting at 1st level, when you cast a spell of 1st-level or higher you gain a temporary flying speed equal to your remaining movement speed, that lasts until the end of your current turn. If you end your movement in the air you fall to the ground, taking appropriate falling damage. While flying with this ability you do not provoke opportunity attacks.

In addition, your connection to elemental air allows you to speak, read, and write Auran. This allows you to communicate with creatures that speak Primordial and it’s other dialects: Aquan, Ignan, and Terran.

sheet.description: When you cast a spell of 1st-level or higher you gain a temporary flying speed equal to your remaining movement speed, that lasts until the end of your current turn. You can speak Primordial and its other dialects.

description.p: Your control over the storm within you grows, empowering your physical form against tempestuous magic. Beginning at 6th level you are resistant to lightning and thunder damage.

In addition, whenever you cast a spell of 1st-level or higher that deals lightning or thunder damage, stormy magic to erupts from you. Creatures of your choice that you can see within 15 feet of you must make a Dexterity Saving throw. They to take 2d6 lightning or thunder damage (your choice) on a failed save, and half as much on a success.

When this ability activates, you can expend additional sorcery points to increase the damage. For each additional sorcery point you expend, you deal an extra 1d6 damage, up to a maximum total of 6d6 damage from this ability.

sheet.description: Whenever you cast a spell of 1st-level or higher that deals lightning or thunder damage, creatures of your choice that you can see within 15 feet of you must make a Dexterity Saving throw. They to take 2d6 lightning or thunder damage (your choice) on a failed save, and half as much on a success. When this ability activates, you can expend additional sorcery points to increase the damage. For each additional sorcery point you expend, you deal an extra 1d6 damage, up to a maximum total of 6d6 damage from this ability.

description.p: In addition to controlling the storm within, your affinity for the winds allows you to exert control over the weather around you. Starting at 6th level, you can control existing weather conditions in the following ways:

ul.li: If it is raining, as an action, you can stop the rain from falling in a 20-foot radius sphere centered on you. You can end this effect as a bonus action on your turn.

If it is windy, as a bonus action, you can change the direction the wind blows within a 100-foot radius sphere centered on you. The wind blows in the direction you choose until the end of your next turn.

sheet.description: If it is raining, as an action, you can stop the rain from falling in a 20-foot radius sphere centered on you. You can end this effect as a bonus action on your turn. If it is windy, as a bonus action, you can change the direction the wind blows within a 100-foot radius sphere centered on you. The wind blows in the direction you choose until the end of your next turn.

description.p: Beginning at 14th level, your power over the wind allows you to fly. You gain a flying speed equal to your movement speed.
In addition, you can expend 9 sorcery points to cast the wind walk spell, which counts as a sorcerer spell for you.

sheet.description: You can cast wind walk.

description.p: The storm within you has made you more elemental than mortal. Starting at 18th level, you do not need to eat, drink, or sleep, and you are immune to lightning and thunder damage.

In addition, when you take damage from a creature within 60 feet that you can see, you can use your reaction to rebuke them with elemental air. The attacking creature must make a Dexterity saving throw, and on a failed save they take lighting or thunder damage (your choice) equal to your sorcerer level.

sheet.description: when you take damage from a creature within 60 feet that you can see, you can force the attacking creature to make a Dexterity saving throw, and on a failed save they take {{level:sorcerer}} lighting or thunder damage (your choice). In addition, you no longer need to eat, drink, or sleep.

description.p: Within you dwells a drop of pure elemental water. You have a deep connection to the oceans, babbling brooks, and the frigid waters of frozen lakes. How did you come to wield the power of elemental waters? Did you inexplicably survive a shipwreck, awakening with oceanic power, or did you drink from a stream flowing from the elemental plane of water?

The lapping of waves, the spray of sea foam on the wind, the ocean depths, all of these things call to your heart. Do you draw upon the soothing properties of the waters, or do you embody the destructive wrath of floods and blizzards?

Whenever you gain a sorcerer level, you can replace one spell you gained from this feature with another spell of the same level. The new spell must be a conjuration or evocation spell from the druid, sorcerer, or wizard spell list.
Waveborn Spells

sheet.description: Whenever you gain a sorcerer level, you can replace one spell you gained from this feature with another spell of the same level.

description.p: The elemental waters within you have fundamentally altered your physical form. Starting at 1st level, you are resistant to cold damage, you gain a swimming speed equal to your movement speed, and you can breathe both air and water.

In addition, your connection to elemental water allows you to speak, read, and write Aquan, the language of elemental water. You can also communicate with creatures that speak Primordial and it’s other dialects: Auran, Ignan, and Terran.

sheet.description: You can breathe both air and water. You can speak Primordial and its other dialects.

description.p: Your watery spells carry a frozen curse. Starting at 1st level, when you deal cold damage to a creature, you can spend 2 additional sorcery points to cover one target of the spell in frost, reducing it’s speed by a number of feet equal to five times your Charisma modifier (minimum of 5 feet).
This reduction lasts until the start of your next turn, unless a creature uses an action to scrape the frost off the target.

sheet.description: When you deal cold damage to a creature, you can spend 2 additional sorcery points to cover one target of the spell in frost, reducing it’s speed by {{curse-depths:speed}} feet.

description.p: Beginning at 6th level, you can assume a watery form when under assault. When you are hit by an attack, you can use your reaction to shift into a liquid form, gaining resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage until the end of your current turn. As part of this reaction you can move your full movement speed without provoking opportunity attacks.
You can use this reaction a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

sheet.description: When you are hit by an attack, you can use your reaction to shift into a liquid form, gaining resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage until the end of your current turn. As part of this reaction you can move your full movement speed without provoking opportunity attacks.

description.p: The elemental water within allows you to move like flowing water. Starting at 14th level, you gain the following benefits:

ul.li: You are resistant to damage from opportunity attacks.
You can move through enemy creature’s spaces, but you cannot end your turn in an enemy creature’s space.
You can squeeze through gaps as narrow as 1 inch.
You can take the Dash action as a bonus action on your turn while you are using your swimming speed.

sheet.description: You are resistant to damage from opportunity attacks. You can move through enemy creature’s spaces, but you cannot end your turn in an enemy creature’s space. You can squeeze through gaps as narrow as 1 inch. While you are using your swimming speed, you can take the Dash action as a bonus action on your turn.

description.p: Upon reaching 18th level, your body is permanently altered by the elemental water within you. You no longer need to eat, drink, or sleep, and you are immune to cold damage.
In addition, as long as you are not incapacitated, when you are hit by an attack that is a critical hit, you can absorb the blow like a liquid, turning the critical hit into a normal hit.

sheet.description: As long as you are not incapacitated, when you are hit by an attack that is a critical hit, you can absorb the blow like a liquid, turning the critical hit into a normal hit. You no longer need to eat, drink, or sleep.

description.p: When you are forced to make a Constitution saving throw to maintain concentration on a spell, you can use your reaction to expend 3 sorcery points and add your Charisma modifier (minimum of 1) to the result of the saving throw.

sheet.description: When you are forced to make a Constitution saving throw to maintain concentration on a spell, you can use your reaction to expend 3 sorcery points and add {{cha-mod:min-one}} to the result of the saving throw.

description.p: When you cast a spell that forces creatures to make a saving throw, you can spend 1 sorcery point to protect a number of creatures equal to your Charisma modifier. Chosen creatures automatically succeed on their saving throw.

sheet.description: When you cast a spell that forces creatures to make a saving throw, you can spend 1 sorcery point to protect a number of creatures equal to your Charisma modifier. Chosen creatures automatically succeed on their saving throw.

description.p: When you cast a spell that forces a creature to make an Intelligence or Charisma saving throw, you can spend 3 sorcery points to change the saving throw to your choice of Intelligence or Charisma.
This Metamagic only changes the initial saving throw, any subsequent saving throws the spell forces a creature to make use the original saving throw.

sheet.description: When you cast a spell that forces a creature to make an Intelligence or Charisma saving throw, you can spend 3 sorcery points to change the saving throw to your choice of Intelligence or Charisma. This Metamagic only changes the initial saving throw, any subsequent saving throws the spell forces a creature to make use the original saving throw.

When you cast a spell that forces a creature to make an Intelligence or Charisma saving throw, you can spend 2 sorcery points to change the saving throw to your choice of Intelligence or Charisma. This Metamagic only changes the initial saving throw, any subsequent saving throws the spell forces a creature to make use the original saving throw.

description.p: When you cast a spell that has a range of 5 feet or greater, you can spend 1 sorcery point to double the range of the spell. When you cast a spell that has a range of touch, you can spend 1 sorcery point to make the range of the spell 30 feet.

sheet.description: When you cast a spell that has a range of 5 feet or greater, you can spend 1 sorcery point to double the range of the spell. When you cast a spell that has a range of touch, you can spend 1 sorcery point to make the range of the spell 30 feet.

description.p: Your innate arcane ability manifests through your personality. You gain proficiency in your choice of Deception, Intimidation, or Persuasion, and your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses the chosen proficiency.
You can select this manifestation more than once, but you must select a different skill proficiency each time.

Your innate arcane ability manifests through your personality. You gain proficiency in your choice of Deception, Intimidation, or Persuasion, and your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses the chosen proficiency.
You can select this manifestation more than once, but you must select a different skill proficiency each time.

Your innate arcane ability manifests through your personality. You gain proficiency in your choice of Deception, Intimidation, or Persuasion, and your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses the chosen proficiency.
You can select this manifestation more than once, but you must select a different skill proficiency each time.
You gain proficiency in Deception and your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make using Deception.
You gain proficiency in Intimidation and your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make using Intimidation.
You gain proficiency in Persuasion and your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make using Persuasion.
When you cast a spell that deals acid, cold, fire, lightning, poison, or thunder damage, you spend 1 sorcery point to change it’s damage type to another type from the list above.

sheet.description: When you cast a spell that deals acid, cold, fire, lightning, poison, or thunder damage, you spend 1 sorcery point to change it’s damage type to another type from the list above.

description.p: When you roll damage for a spell, you can spend 1 sorcery point to reroll a number of the damage dice up to your Charisma modifier. You must use the new rolls. You can use Empowered Spell even if you have already used a different Metamagic during the casting of the spell.

sheet.description: When you roll damage for a spell, you can spend 1 sorcery point to reroll a number of the damage dice up to your Charisma modifier. You must use the new rolls. You can use Empowered Spell even if you have already used a different Metamagic during the casting of the spell.

description.p: When you cast a spell that deals force, necrotic, psychic, or radiant damage, you spend 2 sorcery points to change it’s damage type to another type from the list above.

sheet.description: When you cast a spell that deals force, necrotic, psychic, or radiant damage, you spend 2 sorcery points to change it’s damage type to another type from the list above.
When you cast a spell that deals force, necrotic, psychic, or radiant damage, you spend 1 sorcery point to change it’s damage type to another type from the list above.

description.p: When you cast a spell that has a duration of 1 minute or longer, you can spend 1 sorcery point to double its duration, to a maximum duration of 24 hours.

sheet.description: When you cast a spell that has a duration of 1 minute or longer, you can spend 1 sorcery point to double its duration, to a maximum duration of 24 hours.

description.p: When you cast a spell that forces a creature to make a saving throw to resist its effects, you can spend 3 sorcery points to give one target of the spell disadvantage on its first saving throw made against the spell.

sheet.description: When you cast a spell that forces a creature to make a saving throw to resist its effects, you can spend 3 sorcery points to give one target of the spell disadvantage on its first saving throw made against the spell.

When you cast a spell that forces a creature to make a saving throw to resist its effects, you can spend 2 sorcery points to give one target of the spell disadvantage on its first saving throw made against the spell.

description.p: As an action, you can touch one nonmagical weapon and spend 2 sorcery points to imbue it with a portion of your magic for 1 minute. For the duration, the weapon is considered magical for the purpose of overcoming resistances and immunity to nonmagical attacks.

sheet.description: You can touch one nonmagical weapon and spend 2 sorcery points to imbue it with a portion of your magic for 1 minute. For the duration, the weapon is considered magical for the purpose of overcoming resistances and immunity to nonmagical attacks.

description.p: Your innate arcane will makes you more resistant to effects that would debilitate others. When you fail an Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma saving throw, you can use your reaction to spend 3 sorcery points to re-roll. You must use the new d20 roll, potentially turning it into a success.

sheet.description: When you fail an Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma saving throw, you can use your reaction to spend 3 sorcery points to re-roll. You must use the new d20 roll, potentially turning it into a success.

description.p: When you cast a spell that forces a creature to make a Strength or Dexterity saving throw, you can spend 2 sorcery points to change the initial saving throw to your choice of Strength or Dexterity.
This Metamagic only changes the initial saving throw, any subsequent saving throws the spell forces a creature to make use the spell’s original saving throw.

sheet.description: When you cast a spell that forces a creature to make a Strength or Dexterity saving throw, you can spend 2 sorcery points to change the initial saving throw to your choice of Strength or Dexterity. This Metamagic only changes the initial saving throw, any subsequent saving throws the spell forces a creature to make use the spell’s original saving throw.

When you cast a spell that forces a creature to make a Strength or Dexterity saving throw, you can spend 1 sorcery point to change the initial saving throw to your choice of Strength or Dexterity. This Metamagic only changes the initial saving throw, any subsequent saving throws the spell forces a creature to make use the spell’s original saving throw.

description.p: You can tap into your arcane spark to try and turn failure into success. When you fail an ability check, you can use your reaction to spend 2 sorcery points to re-roll the d20. You must use the new d20 roll, potentially turning it into a success.

sheet.description: When you fail an ability check, you can use your reaction to spend 2 sorcery points to re-roll the d20. You must use the new d20 roll, potentially turning it into a success.

description.p: When you cast a spell that has a casting time of 1 action, you can spend 2 sorcery points to change the casting time to 1 bonus action.

sheet.description: When you cast a spell that has a casting time of 1 action, you can spend 2 sorcery points to change the casting time to 1 bonus action.
When you cast a spell that has a casting time of 1 action, you can spend 1 sorcery point to change the casting time to 1 bonus action.

description.p: When you cast a spell that forces a creature to make a Constitution or Wisdom saving throw, you can spend 2 sorcery points to change the saving throw to your choice of Constitution or Wisdom.
This Metamagic only changes the initial saving throw, any subsequent saving throws the spell forces a creature to make use the original saving throw.

sheet.description: When you cast a spell that forces a creature to make a Constitution or Wisdom saving throw, you can spend 2 sorcery points to change the saving throw to your choice of Constitution or Wisdom. This Metamagic only changes the initial saving throw, any subsequent saving throws the spell forces a creature to make use the original saving throw.

When you cast a spell that forces a creature to make a Constitution or Wisdom saving throw, you can spend 1 sorcery point to change the saving throw to your choice of Constitution or Wisdom. This Metamagic only changes the initial saving throw, any subsequent saving throws the spell forces a creature to make use the original saving throw.

description.p: When you cast a spell that requires you to make a spell attack roll or that forces a target to make a Dexterity saving throw, you can spend 1 sorcery point to ignore the effects of half- and three-quarters cover against targets of the spell.

sheet.description: When you cast a spell that requires you to make a spell attack roll or that forces a target to make a Dexterity saving throw, you can spend 1 sorcery point to ignore the effects of half- and three-quarters cover against targets of the spell.

description.p: As an action, you can spend a number of sorcery points to fortify your physical form. For each sorcery point you expend you gain 1d4 temporary hit points. The maximum number of sorcery points you can spend as part of this ability is equal to your proficiency bonus.

sheet.description: For each sorcery point you expend up to {{proficiency}}, you gain 1d4 temporary hit points.

description.p: When you cast a spell, you can spend 1 sorcery point to cast it without any somatic or verbal components.

sheet.description: When you cast a spell, you can spend 1 sorcery point to cast it without any somatic or verbal components.

description.p: When you cast a spell that targets only one creature or object and doesn’t have a range of self, you can spend a number of sorcery points equal to the spell’s level to target a second target of your choice, in range, with the same spell (1 sorcery point if the spell is a cantrip). To be eligible, a spell must be incapable of targeting more than one creature or object at the spell’s current level.

sheet.description: When you cast a spell that targets only one creature or object and doesn’t have a range of self, you can spend a number of sorcery points equal to the spell’s level to target a second target of your choice, in range, with the same spell (1 sorcery point if the spell is a cantrip).

When you cast a spell that targets only one creature or object and doesn’t have a range of self, you can spend a number of sorcery points equal to the spell’s level minus 1 to target a second target of your choice, in range, with the same spell (1 sorcery point if the spell is a cantrip).

description.p: When you cast a spell and miss with an attack roll, you can spend 2 sorcery points to re-roll one of the attack rolls. You must use the result of the new roll.

sheet.description: When you cast a spell and miss with an attack roll, you can spend 2 sorcery points to re-roll one of the attack rolls. You must use the result of the new roll.
When you cast a spell and miss with an attack roll, you can spend 1 sorcery point to re-roll one of the attack rolls. You must use the result of the new roll.

description.p: When you cast a spell that forces a creature to make a saving throw, you can spend 3 sorcery point to change the saving throw to a random result. Roll 1d12, the spell’s initial saving throw now targets the ability from the list below.

sheet.description: When you cast a spell that forces a creature to make a saving throw, you can spend 3 sorcery point to change the saving throw to a random result.
When you cast a spell that forces a creature to make a saving throw, you can spend 2 sorcery point to change the saving throw to a random result.
